content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Locate an open-source conversational AI model on Hugging Face, trained in English and list its main features and applications.  Please interact with https://huggingface.co/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to search for an open-source conversational model. Use search box.
Action: Type [46]; blenderbot-3B
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to see additional details of model card further down the page for features.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Scroll more down to find "Model description", "Intended uses", etc.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to scroll a bit upwards to locate sections like ‚ÄúModel description‚Äù, ‚ÄúIntended Use‚Äù that outline features/applications.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to see the rest of the ‚ÄúModel description‚Äù section beneath current heading for features and uses.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to inspect earlier part of model card for headings like ‚ÄúIntended use,‚Äù ‚ÄúUsage,‚Äù ‚ÄúLimitations,‚Äù etc. We scrolled too far down toward Spaces; scroll slightly up.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to view further sections below dataset‚Äîlikely ‚ÄúIntended Uses‚Äù, ‚ÄúLimitations‚Äù etc.‚Äîto collect feature details.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
[1777] RootWebArea 'facebook/blenderbot-3B ¬∑ Hugging Face' focused: True url: https://huggingface.co/facebook/blenderbot-3B
	[2083] main ''
		[2483] button ''
		[2549] StaticText 'Building open-domain chatbots is a challenging area for machine learning research. While prior work has shown that scaling neural models in the number of parameters and the size of the data they are trained on gives improved results, we show that other ingredients are important for a high-performing chatbot. Good conversation requires a number of skills that an expert conversationalist blends in a seamless way: providing engaging talking points and listening to their partners, both asking and answering questions, and displaying knowledge, empathy and personality appropriately, depending on the situation. We show that large scale models can learn these skills when given appropriate training data and choice of generation strategy. We build variants of these recipes with 90M, 2.7B and 9.4B parameter neural models, and make our models and code publicly available. Human evaluations show our best models are superior to existing approaches in multi-turn dialogue in terms of engagingness and humanness measurements. We then discuss the limitations of this work by analyzing failure cases of our models.'

Action: Scroll WINDOW; up

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.

		[2549] StaticText 'Building open-domain chatbots is a challenging area for machine learning research. While prior work has shown that scaling neural models in the number of parameters and the size of the data they are trained on gives improved results, we show that other ingredients are important for a high-performing chatbot. Good conversation requires a number of skills that an expert conversationalist blends in a seamless way: providing engaging talking points and listening to their partners, both asking and answering questions, and displaying knowledge, empathy and personality appropriately, depending on the situation. We show that large scale models can learn these skills when given appropriate training data and choice of generation strategy. We build variants of these recipes with 90M, 2.7B and 9.4B parameter neural models, and make our models and code publicly available. Human evaluations show our best models are superior to existing approaches in multi-turn dialogue in terms of engagingness and humanness measurements. We then discuss the limitations of this work by analyzing failure cases of our models.'

ANSWER; 
Open-source conversational AI model on Hugging Face  
Model: facebook/blenderbot-3B  

Main features  
‚Ä¢ Size ‚Äì about 3 billion (‚âà2.7 B) parameters, Transformer encoder-decoder architecture.  
‚Ä¢ Language ‚Äì trained primarily on English dialogue and document corpora (Blended Skill Talk and other ParlAI datasets).  
‚Ä¢ Open-domain capability ‚Äì can hold multi-turn, free-form conversations rather than being restricted to a single task.  
‚Ä¢ Blended skills ‚Äì able to display knowledge, empathy, ask/answer questions and show personality, making talks more engaging.  
‚Ä¢ Publicly released weights, training code and research paper (‚ÄúRecipes for building an open-domain chatbot‚Äù) under an open license.  
‚Ä¢ Runs with the Hugging Face text-generation pipeline and can be served locally or via cloud inference providers.  
‚Ä¢ Good human evaluation scores for ‚Äúengagingness‚Äù and ‚Äúhumanness‚Äù compared with earlier chatbots.  

Typical applications  
‚Ä¢ Building chatbots for customer support, entertainment or personal assistants.  
‚Ä¢ Research and prototyping in conversational AI, dialogue safety, evaluation, and response generation.  
‚Ä¢ Integrating into social-chat features in games, virtual worlds or educational tools.  
‚Ä¢ Serving as a baseline or fine-tune starting point for domain-specific conversational agents.
Format ERROR: Both 'Thought' and 'Action' should be included in your reply.

Thought: I have gathered the necessary information on an English-trained, open-source conversational model (facebook/blenderbot-3B). Ready to present its features and applications.

Action: ANSWER; 
Model located on Hugging Face: facebook/blenderbot-3B (open-source, English).

Main features  
‚Ä¢ Size & architecture ‚Äì ~3 B parameters, Transformer encoder-decoder.  
‚Ä¢ Training data ‚Äì English open-domain dialogue corpora (e.g., Blended Skill Talk and other ParlAI datasets).  
‚Ä¢ Open-domain capability ‚Äì handles multi-turn, free-form conversations.  
‚Ä¢ Blended conversational skills ‚Äì knowledge sharing, empathy, question-asking/answering, personality.  
‚Ä¢ Released assets ‚Äì public weights, training code, and research paper (‚ÄúRecipes for building an open-domain chatbot‚Äù).  
‚Ä¢ Human evaluation ‚Äì rated highly for engagingness and humanness versus previous chatbots.  
‚Ä¢ Easy deployment ‚Äì usable through Hugging Face pipelines or self-hosted inference.

Typical applications  
‚Ä¢ Customer-support or personal-assistant chatbots.  
‚Ä¢ Research & prototyping in conversational AI, safety, and evaluation.  
‚Ä¢ Educational or entertainment chat agents in games/virtual worlds.  
‚Ä¢ Fine-tuning starting point for domain-specific conversation systems.
